Award.AwardTitle: CSBR: Living Stocks: The Bacillus Genetic Stock Center, an established key resource for a diverse and dynamic scientific community
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to the Bacillus Genetic Stock Center (BGSC) at the Ohio State University to support a central repository for maintaining, documenting, publicizing, and distributing a standardized collection comprising important strains of the bacterial genus Bacillus and its relatives. Bacillus plays a vital role in microbiology research. They synthesize a wide range of antibiotics, fine chemicals, vitamins, and industrial enzymes and serve as production platforms for biofuels and ecofriendly pesticides. Some species are useful as probiotics or in vaccine production; others play important roles in sterility assurance, food safety, and bioterrorism prevention. Bacillus research provides insights into bacterial physiology, development, and behavior. Accessioned cultures are stored cryogenically at a secure site at the Ohio State University. This award facilitates the provision of standardized cultures at a reasonable cost to qualified scientists and educators.

Each year, BGSC strains are used for hundreds of innovative projects, resulting in peer-reviewed publications and US patents. In addition, the BGSC supports undergraduate lab experiences and high school science fair projects. This award will support and strengthen the nation's scientific infrastructure by ensuring that this resource remains available to America's science and education communities. Additional information on strain data and community outreach programs is publicly available on the BGSC website (http://bgsc.org) and integrated into Bacillus gene and genome databases in the USA and Europe.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

The primary goal of the Bacillus Genetic Stock Center (BGSC) is to "maintain genetically characterized strains, cloning vectors, and bacteriophage for the genus Bacillus and to distribute these materials without prejudice to qualified scientists and educators throughout the world." The BGSC serves the scientific research and education communities as the steward of the rich legacy of strains that have been produced by previous generations and the exciting new tools that continueto be created in our day. This project has allowed the BGSC to continue to expand its collection, to develop new products, and to extend its services to a growing community of educators and research scientists.

Intellectual Merit

During the four-year funding period, the BGSC demonstrated its ability to support advances in both basic and applied microbiological research. It maintained and distributed strains from the world's largest collection of documented, curated stocks from the important model organism, Bacillus subtilis. It acquired strain libraries with individual knockouts of non-essential genes and tunable "knockdown" mutants of essential genes, opening a new era of discovery. The BGSC also maintained and collected stocks from related species that are crucial to research efforts in agriculture (B. thuringiensis and Paenibacillus polymyxa), public health (B. thuringiensis and Lysinibacillus sphaericus), and biotechnology (B. subtilis, B. licheniformis, Geobacillus, and many more). During the funding period, BGSC bacterial strains have been used in at least 457 peer-reviewed publications and 52 US patents. These figures demonstrate the merit and usefulness of the BGSC collection.

Broader Impacts

The BGSC is a significant part of the infrastructure supporting microbiology, biotechnology, and science education. This award enabled the BGSC to provide several tangible benefits to society. The collection enhanced the research infrastructure, providing standardized, carefully curated bacterial strains to academic and industrial scientists. It improved the repeatability of published results by making identical stocks available for other investigators. It served STEM education, making safe, documented, affordable strains from a model organism, B. subtilis, available to science educators and their students at all levles. It bolstered national security by maintaining and distributing harmless, nonpathogenic surrogate strains for one of the primary bioterrorism threats, the anthrax pathogen B. anthracis. It encouraged economic competitiveness by providing organisms to serve as production platforms for biofuels, pharmaceuticals, fine chemicals, non-toxic fertilizers and pesticides, and carbon-neutral technologies. It promoted the well-being of individuals in society by facilitating research to address current issues in health care, climate change, food security, and national security.
